thread.title_full: UK tabloid distorts traditional Russian pancake festival into ‘Ultra’ football thug fights

author: RT
title: UK tabloid distorts traditional Russian pancake festival into ‘Ultra’ football thug fights
text:
UK tabloid distorts traditional Russian pancake festival into ‘Ultra’ football thug fights  40 Edited time: 21 Mar, 2017 11:46 Get short URL © mirror.co.uk UK tabloid the Mirror has used the traditional Russian festival of ‘Maslenitsa’, celebrated during the last week before Lent, as part of a “shock investigation” into Russian football hooliganism. 
A video with the title “Russian ‘football fans’ in bizarre refereed ‘fights’”, published on the Mirror website on Monday, was part of an article titled “ Russia's Ultra yobs infiltrated amid warnings England fans could be KILLED at World Cup .” 
The video and accompanying photos purport to show Russian football ‘Ultras’ in “violent action” at a “special festival.” 
The article fails to mention, however, that the event was actually part of Maslenitsa celebrations – the traditional Russian pre-Lent festival, which this year was at the end of February, and in which people eat pancakes and participate in activities such as sledding. 
The fighting shown in the video and photos is the traditional Russian “ wall-to-wall ”(‘ stenka na stenku ’) sparring between men dressed in traditional folk clothes, representing a centuries-old tradition. 
The caption reading “The Ultras in violent action” shows two men in boxing gloves, one of whom is wearing a traditional red Russian shirt called a Kosovorotka. © mirror.co.uk 
Another caption reads “People are living in fear”– apparently referring to fear spread by Russian football hooligans – under a photo showing elderly ladies selling traditional woolen shawls. © mirror.co.uk 
The organizers of the festival at the Izmailovsky Kremlin in Moscow, where the footage was taken, told RT that the event did not involve any football Ultras. 
“We are honestly lost for words regarding the lack of knowledge of Russian traditions,” said press secretary Zhanna Chernenko. 
“It is politicizing traditional male bonding. This is Maslenitsa. The fights are 100 percent staged. There were no harmful blows and there were no Ultras involved. We have been closely working with the fist fighting club for years.” 
Responding to warnings in the article that England fans could be killed if they come to the 2018 World Cup in Russia, Chernenko joked: “We have a trained bear, but it’s not trained to attack British fans.”
